case_title: TANVIR AHMED KHAN vs HAMID MUKHTAR and 3 others
reference_no_or_id: Review Petition No. 474 of 2004 in R.O.R. No. 1693 of 2003
case_number: Review Petition No. 474 of 2004 in R.O.R. No. 1693 of 2003
complaint_summary: Dispute arose over the appointment of Lamberdar of Chak No. 294/GB, Tehsil Toba Tek Singh, following the death of the previous Lamberdar. The petitioner was appointed by the District Officer (Revenue) on 2003-04-14, but the respondent appealed and succeeded in overturning the decision.
investigation_summary: The petitioner argued that he was more qualified, owned more land, and was younger and more capable than the respondent. The respondent relied on a Supreme Court precedent prohibiting the Board of Revenue from adjudicating Lamberdar cases.
judgment_summary: The court accepted the review petition, setting aside the orders of the Executive District Officer (Revenue) and Member (Judicial-V), Board of Revenue, Punjab. The court upheld the original appointment of the petitioner as Lamberdar by the District Officer (Revenue). The Supreme Court precedent in PLD 1965 SC 393 was deemed inapplicable due to updated rules under the West Pakistan Land Revenue Rules, 1968.
Decision_or_verdict: Review petition accepted; petitioner reinstated as Lamberdar.

facts.death_of_lamberdar: Lamberdar of Chak No. 294/GB, Tehsil Toba Tek Singh passed away.
facts.initial_appointment: District Officer (Revenue), Toba Tek Singh appointed Tanvir Ahmed Khan as Lamberdar on 2003-04-14.
facts.appeal_by_respondent: Hamid Mukhtar appealed the appointment, which was accepted by Executive District Officer (Revenue), Toba Tek Singh on 2003-09-02.
facts.revision_petition: Tanvir Ahmed Khan filed a revision petition, dismissed by Member (Judicial-V), Board of Revenue, Punjab on 2004-06-19.

legal_arguments: Petitioner argued preferential qualifications including education (F.Sc vs primary pass), land ownership (76 Kanals vs 8 Kanals), and age.
Respondent argued reliance on Supreme Court precedent (PLD 1965 SC 393) prohibiting Board of Revenue from adjudicating Lamberdar cases.

claims: Impugned orders were against the law and facts.
Petitioner was entitled to appointment based on sound physique, higher education, and land ownership.
Petitioner owned 76 Kanals and 14 Marlas of land compared to respondent's 8 Kanals.
Petitioner had F.Sc education compared to respondent's primary education.
Petitioner was younger and more energetic.
Supreme Court prohibited Board of Revenue from adjudicating Lambardari cases.
Adjudication violated Supreme Court orders in PLD 1965 SC 393.

analysis: Supreme Court ruling in PLD 1965 SC 393 was based on rules superseded by West Pakistan Land Revenue Rules, 1968.
Under section 8 of Board of Revenue Act, 1957, review by Full Board is permissible.
decision: Petitioner has resigned from government service and is prepared to serve as Lamberdar.
Petitioner has more land, better education, and is younger than respondent.
Collector's choice should be given weightage.
judgment.final_order: Review petition accepted. Orders dated 2003-09-02 and 2004-06-19 are set aside. Order dated 2003-04-14 is upheld.

assets.details: Petitioner owns 76 Kanals, 14 Marlas; Respondent owns 8 Kanals.

sections: Section 8 of Board of Revenue Act, 1957
key_issues: Applicability of Supreme Court precedent on Board of Revenue jurisdiction

legal_terms.Lamberdar: Village headman responsible for revenue collection and administrative duties.

words_and_phrases.Preferential Edge: Superior qualifications or advantages in comparison to others.

summary_vector_notes: Dispute over Lamberdar appointment resolved in favor of petitioner based on qualifications, land ownership, and administrative suitability. Supreme Court precedent deemed inapplicable due to updated rules.
